perturbation.original_text: Within thirty (30) days after receipt of a Notice of Dispute, the Parties’ Executive Officers will meet and confer in person or by teleconference and at this meeting will use their reasonable efforts to resolve such dispute.
perturbation.changed_text: Within fifteen (15) days after receipt of a Notice of Dispute, the Parties’ Executive Officers will meet and confer in person or by teleconference and at this meeting will use their best efforts to resolve such dispute.
perturbation.explanation: This change reduces the time frame for executive officer resolution from 30 days to 15 days. While seemingly minor, this could be problematic if the complexity of the dispute requires a longer period for initial attempts at resolution. Depending on the jurisdiction, overly restrictive dispute resolution timelines can be viewed unfavorably, especially if they hinder good-faith negotiation. Furthermore, switching 'reasonable' to 'best' efforts could be interpreted as a higher standard of care. Under New York law, 'best efforts' generally is viewed as a more exacting standard.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law Principles - Good Faith Negotiation

perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees that, during the Term and for a period of [***] years thereafter, such Party and its Affiliates will keep confidential and will not publish or otherwise disclose and will not use for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement (which includes the exercise of any rights or the performance of any obligations hereunder) any Confidential Information furnished to it or its Affiliates by the other Party or its Affiliates pursuant to this Agreement, except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or as otherwise agreed to in writing by the Parties
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party agrees that, during the Term and for a period of one (1) year thereafter, such Party and its Affiliates will keep confidential and will not publish or otherwise disclose and will not use for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement any Confidential Information furnished to it or its Affiliates by the other Party or its Affiliates pursuant to this Agreement
perturbation.explanation: Most jurisdictions recognize that certain trade secrets and confidential data must be protected for a commercially reasonable timeframe. A one-year confidentiality period may be considered insufficient to protect proprietary information, particularly in the pharmaceutical industry, where development cycles and market exclusivity periods often extend far beyond this timeframe. This change creates a scenario where the confidentiality clause is legally insufficient to protect critical business assets beyond the one-year mark, undermining the purpose of including it in the Promotion Agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Law, Contract Law - Adequate Consideration

perturbation.original_text: MMT will keep (and will ensure that its Affiliates and sublicensees keep) such records as are required to determine, in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles or international financial reporting standards, as applicable, and this Agreement and the sums or credits due under this Agreement, including Net Product Sales Amounts. MMT will retain all such books, records and accounts until the later of (a) [***] after the end of the period to which such books, records and accounts pertain and (b) the expiration of the applicable tax statute of limitations (or any extensions thereof), or for such longer period as may be required by Laws.
perturbation.changed_text: MMT will keep such records as are required to determine the sums or credits due under this Agreement, including Net Product Sales Amounts. MMT will retain all such books, records and accounts for two (2) years after the end of the period to which such books, records and accounts pertain.
perturbation.explanation: This modification reduces the record retention period to a fixed two years, disregarding both the applicable tax statute of limitations and any longer periods required by law. In the U.S., the IRS generally requires taxpayers to keep records for three years from the date of filing the original return, or two years from the date the tax was paid, whichever is later. Some states also have longer retention periods. This change introduces non-compliance, as the contracted retention period may not meet the mandatory requirements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: IRS Record Retention Requirements, State Tax Laws
